title: 110_hr5954
content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents as part of Project 112 under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The new section added to title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, allowing for certain diagnosed diseases to be considered incurred or aggravated by service even without evidence during that period. This applies to diseases linked to increased exposure to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during military service involving chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, allowing certain diagnosed diseases to be considered incurred or aggravated by service without evidence. This applies to diseases linked to increased exposure to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during military service involving chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Veterans with these diseases are presumed to have been exposed to the agents unless there is conclusive evidence otherwise. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary for determining the presumption of service connection. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, based on sound medical and scientific evidence of exposure to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during military service. Sound medical and scientific information will be considered, and results must be statistically significant, replicable, and peer-reviewed. For diseases associated with Project 112, a positive association with exposure to biological, chemical, or toxic agents is required for service connection presumption. Compensation for veterans and survivors will be maintained even if the presumption is removed. Project 112, conducted by the Department of Defense and other federal agencies from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD, is defined as a chemical and biological weapons program. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses related to chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must create regulations within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must provide all records of exposed personnel within 30 days. A report on Project 112, including costs, benefits, and participant information, must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. Project 112, conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, included the Shipboard Hazard and Defense Project (Project SHAD). The term "Project 112" refers to the chemical and biological weapons program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must address concerns regarding Project 112, as held by veterans and veterans service organizations.
